newsitem.title: USA: Simpson's house being sold; lawyer grilled on assets.
newsitem.headline: Simpson's house being sold; lawyer grilled on assets.

text.p: O.J. Simpson, ordered to pay $33.5 million to the families of his murdered ex-wife and her friend, is putting his mansion up for sale, lawyers trying to collect the damages said Thursday.

On the third anniversary of the murders of Nicole Brown Simpson and Ronald Goldman, the lawyers spent five hours behind closed doors grilling the ex-football star's business attorney about his client's assets.
Several times they came out into Judge David Perez' court to complain that Leroy "Skip" Taft, Simpson's long-time business attorney, was not forthcoming.
Taft later declined to give any details to reporters outside the Santa Monica courthouse where last Febraury Simpson was found responsible for the murders.
Simpson was sued for wrongful death by the victims' families in civil court following his 1995 acquittal on criminal murder charges.
The former star running-back and later TV and movie actor and advertising pitchman was not in court Thursday.

Lawyers Peter Gelblum and Peter Csato, who represent the Goldman family, told reporters a trustees' sale was scheduled for mid-July for Simpson's Los Angeles home, which is valued at more than $3 million and is facing foreclosure.
However, there was little chance proceeds from the sale would go to the Goldmans since the money was earmarked for the mortgage company and also to pay off Simpson's legal fees.
They said Simpson was currently drawing $25,000 a month pension from his production company, Orenthal Productions.
After taxes he receives around $16,000 a month, though this was probably exempt from paying off the damages award, the lawyers said.
They said they had also complained that $50,000 Simpson was paid for a German TV appearance went to pay other lawyers' fees.

Among Simpson's assets is the Heisman Trophy he won as the top college football player. When asked about it by reporters, Taft replied: "I'm only the business manager, I don't deal in sports trophies."
He became testy when one reporter asked of Simpson: "Is he looking for the real killer today?"
"I haven't spoken to him today," Taft snapped back.
